frameDefinitions: While in motion, an Impactor makes sudden, forcible contact with the Impactee, or two Impactors both move, mutually making forcible contact.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.

A Cognizer produces a Target_symbol which represents, in the Target_representation format, a Content that pre-exists in the form of a Source_symbol in a Source_representation format. ''  'This word is sometimes  translated as ` girl '.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
This frame pertains to noise verbs used to characterize motion.
An Agent causes an Impactor to make sudden, forcible contact with an Impactee, or manipulates two (or more)
frameExamples: The massive metal foot <t>hit</t> the ground with a huge thud.
This word is sometimes <t>translated</t> as ` girl '. CNI
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
He <t>slammed</t> his fist down on the table and bellowed something unintelligible.
listRoleDefinitions: The entity that hits the <fen>Impactee</fen>.
The entity which is hit by the <fen>Impactor</fen>.
The multiple entities that collide.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
This is the person who carries out the translation.
A symbol or set of symbols representing the <fen>Content</fen> in the <fen>Source_representation</fen> format.
The representation system in which the <fen>Content</fen> pre-exists.
A symbol or set of symbols representing the <fen>Content</fen> in the <fen>Target_representation</fen> format.
The representation system into which the <fen>Content</fen> is rendered by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The information that is meant to be represented by the <fen>Source_symbol</fen> and <fen>Target_symbol</fen>.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The location where the translation takes place.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.

The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.  In sentences containing a <fen>Cause</fen>, the <fen>Theme</fen> is typically the NP Object.  In other sentences, the <fen>Theme</fen> is normally the External Argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of Motion.
The <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the Motion.
This role identifies the general <fen>Area</fen> in which motion takes place, used particularly if the motion is understood as following a complex or non-linear path.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the motion event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, <fen>Goal</fen>, or <fen>Area</fen>).
The <fen>Impactee</fen> is the entity which is hit by the <fen>Impactor</fen>.
The <fen>Impactor</fen> is the entity that hits the <fen>Impactee</fen> because of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s efforts.
The <fen>Impactors</fen> are the multiple entities that collide.
The <fen>Agent</fen>  causes an impact.

The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, 
typically non-human, force that causes an <fen>Impactor</fen> to make sudden, 
forcible contact with an Impactee.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen>  when the impact occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The rock</fex> hit the sand with a thump.
The rock hit <fex>the sand</fex> with a thump.
<fex>The car and truck</fex> collided at a combined speed of over 100MPH.
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.

More books were translated <fex>from other languages</fex> into Russian in the 1980s , including record numbers from English , German and French.
Together with the French Prime Minister, Guizot, he translated it into French <fex>as entente cordiale</fex> for King Louis Philippe to use in his speech.
Well they translated it <fex>into Spanish</fex> as 'Uno-Dos-Tres Meneha Meneha!'
She guided me through the dishes available that afternoon and translated <fex>my order</fex> into Spanish for the older woman in the kitchen.
<fex>Last year</fex> I translated a short book on the artist Anne Ratkowski (of the pre-war November Group in Berlin) from German into English.

The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.

<fex>Pat</fex> crunched over the fresh snow.

The fly buzzed <fex>about the room</fex>.

What I want to know is who smacked <fex>my head</fex> with a 10-ton truck?
Those hoodlums strike my car <fex>with water balloons</fex> every day!
Mr. Addams likes to collide <fex>toy trains</fex> at high speed.
<fex>One juggler</fex> was hitting the ceiling with every other ball.
<fex>A violent explosion</fex>rattled the windows.
